Project  The  project  will  (i)  strengthen  Bemobile’s  backbone  infrastructure  for 
Description  telecommunications to reduce its reliance on the legacy infrastructure of 
Telikom PNG (the state-owned telecom service provider), (ii) upgrade and 
expand its existing network in PNG to increase national geographic and 
population  coverage,  and  (iii) continue  the  roll-out  of  its  nationwide 
network in Solomon Islands. 
   
Impact, Outcome,  The project will provide an expansion of telecom service, particularly for 
and Benefits  low-income users, in both PNG and Solomon Islands. The project will 
improve  the  accessibility  and  quality  of  telecom  service  in  PNG  and 
Solomon Islands, particularly in remote and rural areas. The improved 
network  will  enable  better  access  to  information,  including  for  public 
services  delivery,  education,  health,  and  security.  The  increased 
affordability  and  improved  accessibility  will  enable  inclusive  economic 
growth by facilitating access to markets and information and developing 
other businesses relying on telecom service. The project will also support 
the governments' strategies of encouraging private sector participation in 
PNG and Solomon Islands, given the substantial investment required and 
limited  self-financing  capacity  locally.  Support  from  the  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) to Bemobile, particularly in equity, will promote 
good practices in relation to corporate governance and environmental and 
social  management  in  both  PNG  and  Solomon  Islands.  ADB’s  equity 
investment will bring state effective ownership in Bemobile to below 50% 
(a significant transition milestone toward full privatization of Bemobile) and 
further boost the PNG government’s overall privatization program. 
   
Sponsors  GEMS, a private equity fund based in Hong Kong, China  
Telikom PNG, the state-owned telecom company in PNG

ii 
Justification and  ADB assistance for the project is justified based on the value ADB can 
ADB Value-Added  add  to  the  project  and  the  project’s  development  impacts  and 
demonstration effects. ADB will add value through (i) catalyzing, as a 
multilateral agency and reputable infrastructure lender, further commercial 
financing to a sector in the Pacific region which, although thriving, has 
difficulty  attracting  medium-term  commercial  lenders;  (ii) demonstrating 
support  for  sustainable  private  sector  participation,  good  corporate 
governance, and strong social responsibility in the Pacific region, thus 
encouraging entrepreneurs and investors to consider investments in key 
sectors in the Pacific region while inducing competitors to improve their 
service offerings and performance; and (iii) reflecting ADB’s commitment 
to small economies and transferring knowledge and experience. 
 
The project is in line with ADB’s Strategy 2020, Pacific Strategy, and 
country  partnership  strategies  for  PNG  and  Solomon  Islands,  and  it 
supports the governments’ development plans.

I.  THE PROPOSAL

1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
equity investment in, and a loan to, Bemobile Limited for the Bemobile Expansion Project.

2.  Bemobile will use the proceeds of the equity investment and loan to (i) strengthen its  pe

geographic and population coverage. The project will be the first private sector investment by 
the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Solomon Islands.  
 
II.  BACKGROUND AND RATIONALE 
 
A.  Project Identification and Selection 
 
3.  ADB started discussions with Bemobile and its shareholders in September 2009. After 
several significant changes (i.e., the relaunch of the business in PNG in November 2009, 
expansion into Solomon Islands in 2010, and management transition in the first half of 2010), 
the business of Bemobile has shown positive signs of stabilization and improvement. The 
project is in line with ADB’s strategies and is selected for further processing to support its 
operation. 
 
B.  Sector Background  
 
  1.  Papua New Guinea Telecom Market 
 
4.  PNG, with a population of about 6.7 million, is the largest economy in the Pacific region. 
Before 2007, the telecom market in PNG was dominated by the state-owned enterprise, Telikom 
PNG, which had a history of insufficient investment. Telikom’s services were among the most 
expensive in the world. In addition, the country was among those having the poorest access to 
telecom services in the world. The telecom market in PNG could be characterized as having (i) 
high demand for affordable services, (ii) widespread consumer dissatisfaction, and (iii) high 
tariffs and low telephony penetration. 
 
5.  Lack  of reliable fixed-line  infrastructure,  combined  with  reasonable  costs for mobile 
service, has led to fixed-to-mobile substitution. Deregulation of the telecom industry is imminent 
across the Pacific region. In 2002, the National Executive Council of PNG announced planned 
liberalization of the telecom sector, and in September 2006, Digicel PNG and GreenCom (an 
Indonesian-sponsored company) obtained licenses for mobile telecom operations in PNG, while 
Telikom was required to spin-off its mobile telecom business subsidiary. Subsequently, Capital 
Way, a special-purpose vehicle majority-owned by foreign interests, invested in 50% of the 
shares of the subsidiary, newly named Bemobile. Bemobile then relaunched its business in 
November 2009. Presently, the market is dominated by Digicel and, to a lesser extent, Bemobile. 
GreenCom has never launched and is the subject of liquidation proceedings.  
 
6.  The mobile penetration rate in PNG is estimated to be about 28% as of December 2010, 
which indicates the market is still underserved.2 As a reference, the global mobile penetration

7.  Demand growth will stem mainly from two groups: (i) potential customers who can afford  e
n
and  are  willing  to  own  mobile  phones  but  are  not  covered  by  any  mobile  network,  and  dix
(ii) potential customers who currently do not have mobile phones but are already in an area with   4
 
mobile coverage. Further demand is expected to emerge as the market takes shape, coverage 
expands, and tariffs are reduced due to increasing competition. A demographic analysis based 
on estimated data from the United Nations indicates that, in PNG, the 15–60 population age 
group is about 3.3 million. These are the mobile operators’ main target clients and there are 
currently approximately only 1.8 million subscribers.  
 
8.  In March 2009, the National Executive Council approved a comprehensive set of reforms 
for the telecom sector. This sets out a path for staged introduction of open competition in PNG’s 
telecom sector. Subsequently, the National Information and Communications Technology Act, 
2009 came into force on the succession date of 29 October 2010. As part of the new licensing 
regime,  current  licensees  will  be  encouraged  to  migrate  to  the  new  set  of  licenses  on  a 
voluntary basis within a year of the succession date. The act ensures that the new licenses will 
not materially diminish the rights of the current licensees. 
 
9.  ADB, under a separate intervention, provided technical assistance to the competition 
regulator, the Independent Consumer and Competition Commission (ICCC), to develop telecom 
industry codes of practice and interconnection determinations. 4 The ICCC’s information and 
communication technology licensing functions were transferred to the National Information and 
Communications Technology Authority, which was established as an independent regulator. 
The Papua New Guinea Radiocommunications and Telecommunications Technical Authority 
was disbanded on the succession date of 29 October 2010. 
 
2.  Solomon Islands Telecom Market 
 
10.  Solomon Islands, with a population of about 540,000, has one of the fastest-growing 
populations in the world. The country is made up of hundreds of coral atolls and small volcanic 
islands congregated to form an archipelago of nearly 1,000 islands stretching some 1,600 
kilometers. These islands share a total landmass of 28,336 square kilometers, making Solomon 
Islands the second-largest country in the southern Pacific region. However, it is also one of the 
poorest  in  the  region,  with  per  capita  income  of  $1,256  as  of  2009.5 The  population  is 
fragmented into pockets of communities confined to islands distanced by sea and difficult terrain. 
More than 80% of the population lives in small and widely dispersed rural settlements, mostly in 
coastal areas (many of which are extremely remote). Communication between families and 
friends in different parts of the country is a constant challenge, especially considering the lack of 
coverage and prohibitive price of telecommunications. 
 
11.  Economic activity continues to rely on the unsustainable exploitation of the country’s 
forests and high levels of donors’ and development partners’ assistance. The projected decline 
                                                                                                                                                       
mobile penetration rate in PNG and Solomon Islands compared to other developing markets, which is indicative of 
strong unmet demand.

in logging from 2011 and any major reduction in aid flows will pose serious risks to medium-term 
macroeconomic and fiscal stability. Currently, the most pressing issues for the country are 
sustained  economic  growth,  increased  employment  and  income-generating  opportunities, 
access  to  basic  services,  and  improved  human  and  institutional  capacity.  Addressing  the 
multiple root causes that led to social unrest during 1999–2003 also remains a top priority. 
Improved telecommunications could be a significant contributor to, and driver of, these activities. 
 
12.  Many telecom facilities were destroyed during the civil war in 2000 and consequently all 
development of telecom facilities was placed on hold. Solomon Islands is one of the least 
“connected” countries in the world today. As of 2008, fixed line penetration was only 1.6%, while 
mobile penetration was 6.0%.6 Most areas of the country do not have access to any kind of 
communications infrastructure, including broadcast radio.  
 
13.  The  telecom  sector  faces  a  number  of  challenges:  (i)  high  prices,  particularly  for 
international and internet services; (ii) limited coverage in and outside Honiara, the capital city; 
(iii) a limited range of products and services, especially for data; and (iv)a monopolistic market 
structure, which has scope for improved operational efficiency.  
 
14.  Restoration of telecommunications has only progressed slowly, and has been hampered 
by inadequate funding. In 2006, the government planned a review of the monopoly status of 
Solomon Telekom Company to introduce competition in the telecom sector. In 2007, the name 
of Solomon Telekom Company was changed to Our Telekom, which is now mainly providing 
global system for mobile communications (GSM) postpaid and prepaid mobile services in Auki, 
Honiara, Gizo, Munda, and Noro.  
 
15.  Telecom tariffs, particularly for mobile and international calls, have been high relative to 
regional comparators and per capita incomes. Until recently, a 1-minute local mobile phone call 
cost around $0.40 (billed per minute), but in July 2009 this was halved at a stroke, indicating 
potential for further cost reductions and consequential uptake of services. High mobile telecom 
rates are reflected in the cost of SkypeOut calls to Solomon Islands which, at $1.17 per minute, 
are among the highest in the world. Broadband internet costs have declined slightly but are still 
very high—$100/month for an “entry level” 128 kbps connection, $452 for 512 kbps, and $3,351 
for 2 Mbps (fastest). Public access to high-speed broadband internet is mainly limited to Honiara.  
 
16.  The  government  initiated  the  process  of  developing  new  legislation  on 
telecommunications and invited the shareholders of Our Telekom to renegotiate the terms of 
their exclusive license in late 2008. The negotiations concluded in June 2009 with the signing of 
a settlement agreement to terminate the Our Telekom monopoly, phase in competition, and 
transfer  regulatory  functions  such  as  spectrum  and  numbering  management  to  a  new 
independent  regulator.  The  Telecommunications  Act,  2007  was  enacted  by  Parliament  on 
27 August 2009.  
 
17.  Our Telekom’s 15-year license is set to expire in 2017. The license is subject to review 
every 5 years. The ownership structure of the company is as follows: 41.9% Cable and Wireless 
(UK),  7.1%  government,  and  51%  National  Provident  Fund.  The  government  launched  a 
competitive tender for a second mobile license in July 2009, and awarded Bemobile a 15-year 
non-exclusive license in December 2009. It has been announced that a third mobile license 
could be issued in 2011.

C.  Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 
 
1.  Consistency with Strategy 2020 
 
19.  The project is consistent with ADB’s Strategy 2020, which identifies infrastructure as one 
of  the  five  core  areas  where  ADB  will  employ  its  financial  and  institutional  resources  to 
maximize results, efficiency, and impact.7 ADB will invest in infrastructure to improve transport 
and communication connectivity within and between its developing member countries. Under 
Strategy 2020, ADB’s infrastructure operations emphasize private sector engagement.  
 
20.  Under Strategy 2020, inclusive growth is one of three complementary strategic agendas 
upon which ADB will focus. The project will directly improve people’s access to markets and 
basic productive assets, thereby helping to achieve inclusive growth in PNG and Solomon 
Islands.  
 
2.  Consistency with Country Strategy 
 
21.  The project is in line with ADB’s Pacific Approach 8 and its country partnership strategies 
in PNG9 and Solomon Islands.10 One key result area identified in ADB’s Pacific Approach is 
improved provision, operation, and maintenance of physical infrastructure so as to support an 
environment conducive to the private sector.11 Information and communication technology has 
also been identified as one of the operational priorities. In the PNG country partnership strategy, 
infrastructure is the focus of ADB and its private sector operations. In Solomon Islands, ADB's 
private sector development strategy aims to provide support to the government by improving the 
business environment through greater private sector participation in different sectors of the 
economy.   
 
3.  Consistency with Other ADB Operations 
 
22.  In 2009, ADB provided financial assistance to Digicel, the other mobile operator in PNG, 
which was the first ADB private sector infrastructure investment in the Pacific region. 12 The 
project is another ADB commitment in the telecom sector, showing ADB’s continued effort to

III.  THE PROJECT 
 
A.  Project Description 
 
1.  Project Design 
 
23.  Bemobile’s existing networks in PNG and Solomon Islands are based on the global 
system  for  mobile  communications  (GSM),  the  most  popular  standard  for  mobile 
telecommunications in the world. 
 
24.  Bemobile will add additional switches, upgrade its billing system, and expand its network 
coverage. Most of the new network sites are in rural areas. The equipment, the cost of which 
represents less than 50% of the total capital expenditure, is expected to be purchased from 
foreign  suppliers.  However,  civil  works  and  other  services  have  been  contracted  to  local 
contractors and suppliers, directly benefiting the local economy. In addition, system upgrades 
will support the initial deployment of broadband data and new value-added services including 
mobile banking. 
 
2.  Project Outputs and Outcome 
 
25.  The project will result in improved and expanded mobile telecom network facilities, thus 
enabling  more  subscribers  to  afford  and  use  telecom  services  in  line  with  international 
standards. The outcome of the project will be increased penetration of high-quality, affordable 
mobile telecom services in  PNG and the Solomon Islands.  
 
B.  Development Impact 
 
1.  Contribution to Economic Growth and Poverty Reduction 
 
26.  Since its relaunch, Bemobile has substantially lowered mobile calling prices in PNG. 
Currently the tariff of Bemobile is cheaper than the other mobile operators in PNG and Solomon 
Islands. Through project implementation, tariffs are expected to continuously decrease as the 
result of enhanced economies of scale and increased competition. Bemobile will also be able to 
provide more reliable services after its backbone is strengthened through the project. Hence, 
the project will increase the affordability and reliability of telecom services, particularly for low-
income users, across PNG and Solomon Islands. The project will also expand the network 
coverage in PNG and Solomon Islands, and the improved accessibility will most benefit users in 
rural, remote areas where telecom service is limited or nonexistent. The increased affordability 
and  improved  accessibility  will  enable  inclusive  economic  growth  by  facilitating  access  to 
markets and information, such as by providing remote access to bank accounts and updated 
market information for fishers and farmers. For example, buyers will be able to contact a fisher 
to place orders while he or she is fishing at sea.  
 
27.  The project will significantly improve Bemobile’s existing networks in PNG and Solomon 
Islands.  After  project  implementation,  customers  will  enjoy  better  access  to  information, 
including  in  relation  to  public  services,  education,  health,  and  security.  For  these  island

28.  The project supports the Government of PNG’s Medium Term Development Plan, 2011–
2015,18 which has a primary goal of building the foundation for increased economic growth and 
prosperity. It promotes investment and competition in key sectors that enable increased growth 
and  facilitate  efficient  government  expenditure.  Improved  access  to  information  and 
communication technology is highlighted as crucial in facilitating business and income-earning 
opportunities,  while  aiding  the  efficient  delivery  of  public  services,  including  health  and 
education.  Recent  advances  in  the  outreach  of  mobile  telecom  services,  following  the 
introduction of competition, are credited as having had major social and economic benefits, 
while investment in telecommunications has been one of the main drivers of economic growth in 
2005–2009. The plan further highlights the government’s commitment to the continued reform 
and liberalization of the telecom sector. 
 
29.  The project is also consistent with the Government of Solomon Island’s broad-ranging 
Medium Term Development Strategy, 2008–2010,19 which was adopted by the government in 
2008. Given the post-conflict nature of the country, the overarching goal of the strategy is post-
conflict reconciliation. The strategy recognizes, however, that to achieve economic growth and 
prosperity,  Solomon  Islands  needs  to  create  an  environment  that  promotes  private  sector 
activity.  In  particular,  the  strategy  highlights  improving  access  to,  and  affordability  of, 
telecommunications as a priority. While the current strategy ended in 2010, a new national 
strategic plan is under development with ADB assistance. The new plan is also likely to accord 
a high priority to growth led by the private sector. 
 
2.  Private Sector Development 
 
30.  The  project  will  also  provide  direct  development,  employment,  and  business 
opportunities to staff, dealers, and contractors in underdeveloped areas of the countries. The 
partial privatization of Bemobile in 2008 was recognized as the most important event in recent 
private sector development in PNG, and the success of Bemobile has a direct impact on the 
overall development of the private sector in the country. Meanwhile, Bemobile’s investment in 
Solomon Islands is also considered a major milestone in private sector development in that 
country. ADB’s support to Bemobile in both countries will promote further participation of the 
private sector, which is playing an increasing role in economic growth in PNG and Solomon 
Islands.

C.  Environmental and Social Dimensions 
 
1.  Environmental Safeguards 
 
31.  ADB’s environmental due diligence for the project has included a review of the potential 
environmental impacts related to the project’s locations, planning and design, construction, and 
operation. These impacts are assessed to be either insignificant or temporary in nature. The 
project is unlikely to have adverse environmental impacts. Therefore, the project is classified 
environment category B in accordance with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009). The 
proposed ADB assistance will finance improvement and expansion of existing facilities covering 
multiple  sites.  An  environmental  and  social  compliance  audit  was  undertaken  to  assess 
Bemobile’s current environment and social management system and the company's past and 
current  performance  against  the  objectives,  principles,  and  requirements  of  the  Safeguard 
Policy Statement. An initial environmental examination report was also prepared by Bemobile in 
accordance with the Safeguard Policy Statement.  
 
2.  Social Dimensions 
 
32.  Installation of mobile base stations will require limited space for roof- or wall-mounted 
antennas or a small parcel of leased land. Depending on the type and height of towers, ground 
is cleared of vegetation at each site, providing sufficient space to store tower beams and other 
components during construction and to establish a small temporary workforce camp.  
 
33.  Social safeguards. The corporate environmental and social audit findings show that 
Bemobile has adopted strict selection criteria in line with its Site Acquisition Process20 to avoid 
involuntary resettlement and adverse indigenous people impacts. For each telecom tower site, 
Bemobile identifies several sites and follows strict selection criteria. 
 
34.  In PNG and Solomon Islands, the indigenous population is almost entirely Melanesian, 
although a small number of Polynesians reside north of Bougainville Island. There are estimated 
to be more than 1,000 cultural groups and around 840 indigenous languages in PNG due to 
fragmentation created by terrain. Significant ethnic distinctions exist between population groups 
in  different  parts  of  the  country  but,  despite  the  number  of  groups,  none  are  considered 
minorities. In Solomon Islands, minority groups include Polynesians and i-Kiribati. The central 
chain of high islands was historically occupied by Melanesians, while outlying islands (including 
coral atolls) were occupied by different Polynesian cultural groups. The i-Kiribati resettled from 
the  Gilbert  Islands  (Kiribati)  from  the  1950s  onward  due  to  land  shortages.  Around  80 
Melanesian and five Polynesian languages are spoken.  
 
35.  Bemobile’s  Site  Acquisition  Process requires  that  only  sites  that  will  not  entail  any 
physical or economic displacement of people or cause any adverse impacts on customary 
owners of land will be selected.  
 
36.  The land requirements for the mobile base stations are minimal, and the selection 
criteria adopted ensure that the project will entail no involuntary resettlement impacts. The site 
acquisition procedure is transparent and ensures that any customary owned lands are leased 
with the consent of their owners. From the perspective of the Safeguard Policy Statement, the 
project is classified category C under involuntary resettlement and indigenous peoples.

D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Licenses and Permits 
 
38.  A  nationwide  GSM  mobile  license  and  spectrum  assignment  underpins  Bemobile’s 
operation. In PNG, Telikom was issued a mobile carrier license by the Independent Consumer 
and Competition Commission (ICCC) under the Telecommunications Act, 1996 on 18 July 2002 
for a period of 15 years. Telikom assigned its rights under the mobile carrier license to Bemobile 
in 2008. Telikom was also a party to the spectrum usage agreement with the Papua New 
Guinea Radiocommunications and Telecommunications Technical Authority dated 15 October 
2007 that allows it to use spectrum in connection with the provision of the mobile carrier license. 
Telikom has also exclusively sublicensed its rights under the agreement to Bemobile. On 21 
August 2009, Bemobile was granted a “carrier grade” value-added services license by the ICCC 
for a period of 15 years. In Solomon Islands, Bemobile was awarded a 15-year license in 
December 2009 along with spectrums. Together, the license and agreements give Bemobile a 
nonexclusive right to provide mobile voice and data services based on the GSM and WCDMA 
(3G) standards in PNG and Solomon Islands. 
 
2.  Interconnection 
 
39.  In PNG interconnection is mandated by the Telecommunications Act, 1996 and no 
significant change is expected under the National Information and Communications Technology 
Act. Bemobile is interconnected both domestically and internationally and maintains several 
interconnection  agreements.  On  the  domestic  side  Bemobile  is  interconnected  with  both 
Telikom and Digicel.  
 
40.  In Solomon Islands, Bemobile has signed an interconnection agreement with Solomon 
Telekom. 
 
3.  Construction Arrangements 
 
41.  The project will expand Bemobile’s existing network It is expected that all the contractors 
and equipment suppliers are reputable and were involved in the works at the existing sites.  
   
42.  All  building  activities  during  planning,  site  survey,  site  acquisition,  construction, 
installation, transmission, and upgrades will be carried out simultaneously on a rolling schedule. 
Bemobile is continuously engaged in, and has demonstrated ability in, planning and executing 
the successful design and construction of this type of infrastructure.  
 
4.  Operations Arrangements 
 
43.  Bemobile’s business is highly automated, as is the standard in the mobile telecom 
industry. For PNG, Bemobile has key equipment in the form of switches in its headquarters in

9 
Port Moresby as well as base station controllers and/or media gateways in three key regional 
cities.  In  Solomon  Islands  all  key  equipment  is  located  in  Honiara.  All  base  stations  and 
associated equipment across the network operate unattended and are fully automated. All calls, 
SMS  messages,  data  services,  and  applications  are  processed  by  computers.  The  labor-
intensive  processes  are  network  and  customer  service.  However,  customer  service  is 
outsourced. 
 
44.  As is the case in most parts of the world, Bemobile’s subscriber base is dominated by 
prepaid customers. The subscribers load or “top up” their account by purchasing prepaid (top-up) 
cards. Top-ups are available in various denominations as low as K5 and can be purchased from 
many  different  types  of  retailers,  street  vendors,  and  kiosks.  Bemobile  runs  a  variety  of 
promotions  that  reward  prepaid  subscribers  with  extra  free  top-up.  Bemobile  subsidizes 
handsets as part of its marketing and promotion campaign, as sales and promotional offers are 
made with a handset bundled with a subscriber identification module (SIM) card and some initial 
calling minutes. A majority of the low-end handsets are partially subsidized to the consumer so 
as to accelerate sales. However, the handsets are “locked” so that the phone can only be used 
on the Bemobile network. There is also a significant demand for high-end handsets.  
 
45.  Power is  an operational issue for Bemobile, even in urban areas. Many of the sites are 
in rural areas where there is not even the option to connect to the power grid. Therefore all cell 
sites have at least one standby diesel generator. Local maintenance contractors must go to 
most sites, some of which are only accessible via helicopter, at least once every 4–6 weeks to 
refill diesel. However, this is the only significant maintenance needed for the sites.  
 
5.  Anticorruption Policy 
 
46.  Bemobile was advised of ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) and 
policy relating to the Combating of Money Laundering and the Financing of Terrorism (2003). 
Consistent with its commitment to good governance, accountability, and transparency, ADB will 
require  Bemobile  to  institute,  maintain,  and  comply  with  internal  procedures  and  controls 
following international best practice standards for the purpose of preventing corruption, money 
laundering  activities,  or  the  financing  of  terrorism  and  covenant  with  ADB  to  refrain  from 
engaging in such activities. The investment documentation between ADB and Bemobile will 
further allow ADB to investigate any violation or potential violation of these undertakings. 
 
6.  Project Performance Monitoring, Reporting, and Evaluation 
 
47.  Bemobile will continue to provide to the lenders, now including ADB, quarterly unaudited 
financial statements, quarterly operations reports, annual audited financial statements, annual 
operations reports, annual environmental and social monitoring reports, and annual business 
plans. It must report any important changes. ADB will monitor the project with regard to the 
business plans, using information from its own sources and the public domain. Evaluation of the 
project will be on three levels: (i) the success of the project, (ii) economic growth in PNG and 
Solomon Islands generally, and (iii) private sector development in PNG and Solomon Islands.

10   
IV.  THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 
   1
0
 
A.  The Assistance    
 
 
   A
p
1.  Equity Investment  p
e
  n
d
48.  The proposed equity investment will involve ADB’s subscription to up to 6% of the  ix 4
 
outstanding ordinary shares in Bemobile (or to such lesser percentage as can be subscribed to 
for $9 million),22 funded from ADB’s ordinary capital resources.  
 
2.  Loan 
 
49.  The proposed ADB direct loan will be up to $40 million. The loan will be funded using 
ADB’s ordinary capital resources without government guarantee.  
 
B.  Justification for ADB Assistance 
 
50.  ADB’s  proposed  assistance  for  the  project  is  justified  based  on  its  value-added, 
development impacts, and demonstration effects. ADB will further add value as follows: 
 
(i)  The project will catalyze commercial financing and development financing into a 
much-needed infrastructure sector in both PNG and Solomon Islands. The local 
debt market is limited at present, particularly for medium-term financing. Offshore 
commercial and export credit sources are reluctant to extend uncovered financing to 
businesses in PNG and Solomon Islands due to perceived country risk issues. 
(ii)  The project will promote sustainable private sector participation with good corporate 
governance  and  strong  environmental  and  social  responsibility  in  PNG  and 
Solomon  Islands.  This  will  encourage  entrepreneurs  and  financial  investors  to 
consider investments in key sectors in PNG, Solomon Islands, and the Pacific 
region. 
(iii)  The  project  will  promote  free  competition  by  inducing  incumbent  operators  to 
improve their service and performance in providing infrastructure services at a cost-
effective level. 
(iv)  The project will augment strong commitment of ADB’s private sector operations to 
support small-scale economies within its developing members. In particular, the 
project helps to encourage the transfer of capital, technology, and experience from 
experienced international sponsors to the developing member countries. 
 
C.  Assurances 
 
51.  Consistent  with  the  Agreement  Establishing  the  Asian  Development  Bank, 26  the 
governments of PNG and Solomon Islands have been requested to confirm that they have no 
objection  to  the  proposed  assistance  to  Bemobile.  ADB  will  enter  into  suitable  finance 
documentation, in form and substance satisfactory to ADB, following approval of the proposed 
assistance by the Board of Directors.   
 
                                                
22  The initial ADB equity investment will be no more than $8 million, and the remaining will be the contingent for future 
capital calls. 
26 ADB. 1966. Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank. Manila.

11 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
52.  I am satisfied that the proposed equity investment and loan would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve 
 
(i)  the equity investment of up to $9,000,000 in Bemobile Limited for the Bemobile 
Expansion Project from ADB’s ordinary capital resources; and 
(ii)  the loan of up to $40,000,000 to Bemobile Limited for the Bemobile Expansion 
Project from ADB's ordinary capital resources. 
. 
 
 
 
Haruhiko Kuroda 
  President 
4 March 2011
